update.description:
* updated gzscene loadmesh to load files

* added walkway model to test files utils

* sdfparser accepts files as well as uris tests added

* added house_2 files

* cleaning the PR

To test the PR have a look at the last three tests in the `gzscene_test.js`.

P.S. this PR only upgrades gzweb to accepts files, it doesn't have an example or a `FileReader` API like the declined one.

Happy reviewing xD.

content.raw:
The scene has other functions like `createPlane`, `createBox`, etc. How about `createFromSDF`?

And note that those functions don't automatically add the created object to the scene, instead, they return an object, and it is the responsibility of whoever called create to add the created object either to the scene or another object.

Also, don't forget to remove the function from spawnmodel ;)
content.html:
The scene has other functions like createPlane, createBox, etc. How about createFromSDF?

And note that those functions don't automatically add the created object to the scene, instead, they return an object, and it is the responsibility of whoever called create to add the created object either to the scene or another object.

Also, don't forget to remove the function from spawnmodel ;)

update.title: Sdfparser accept files

content.raw: Right this makes much sense, since we've removed the spawning from the `sdfviewer` the right place for this function would be the `gzscene`.
content.html: Right this makes much sense, since we've removed the spawning from the sdfviewer the right place for this function would be the gzscene.

content.raw:
This function is currently not being used, right? It feels to me that `SpawnModel` might not be the best place for it. The model spawner's role is to manage the process of the user inserting a new model into the scene. It spawns a temporary preview of the model, which moves with the mouse hover / touch drag, and on mouse click / touch end, the preview is deleted and a request is sent to the server. This function seems to have no relation to that, but maybe I'm missing something.

How about moving this to `gzscene`? The scene could keep its own reference to an `sdfparser`. Then the SDF viewer would not need `gzspawnmodel`.
content.html:
This function is currently not being used, right? It feels to me that SpawnModel might not be the best place for it. The model spawner's role is to manage the process of the user inserting a new model into the scene. It spawns a temporary preview of the model, which moves with the mouse hover / touch drag, and on mouse click / touch end, the preview is deleted and a request is sent to the server. This function seems to have no relation to that, but maybe I'm missing something.

How about moving this to gzscene? The scene could keep its own reference to an sdfparser. Then the SDF viewer would not need gzspawnmodel.

content.raw:
They are different functions, so there is no way for a person looking at this one to know they should look at the other function for a deeper documentation ;)

Also, the current documentation for `loadMeshFromString` doesn't explain what's the URI's role.

We have to keep in mind that other people (or even us) might come back to this code years from now and wonder what was going on, users shouldn't need to dig through the code to understand what a parameter is supposed to do.
content.html:
They are different functions, so there is no way for a person looking at this one to know they should look at the other function for a deeper documentation ;)

Also, the current documentation for loadMeshFromString doesn't explain what's the URI's role.

We have to keep in mind that other people (or even us) might come back to this code years from now and wonder what was going on, users shouldn't need to dig through the code to understand what a parameter is supposed to do.

content.raw:
Oh now I remember why I didn't remove the Uri :sweat_smile: 

The model Uri is concluded from the model's sdf, so there is no need to remove it, because it is just something internal.

It would be useful if we wanted to load a model using both the `string` api and the `Uri`'s one, I believe leaving it would allow us to do so.
content.html:
Oh now I remember why I didn't remove the Uri

The model Uri is concluded from the model's sdf, so there is no need to remove it, because it is just something internal.

It would be useful if we wanted to load a model using both the string api and the Uri's one, I believe leaving it would allow us to do so.

content.raw:

content.raw:
So like, you would pass both the OBJ file URI and the OBJ file's contents, right? For example:

~~~
loadMeshFromString('assets/XXX.obj', undefined, undefined, function(mesh){}, 
    ['# 3ds Max Wavefront OBJ Exporter v0.97b - (c)2007 guruware
    # File Created: 30.11.2016 17:17:21
    mtllib mesh.mtl
    #
    # object Walkway_45_Right
    #
    v  -762.0001 1077.6306 -0.1269
    ..........
    ']);
~~~

In this case, I'd assume whatever I passed to `files` will be loaded. So I'm not sure why the code would ever go read `assets/XXX.obj`.
content.html:
